Literature Review: Statistical methods for exoplanet detection with radial velocities have been a topic of increasing interest in recent years, driven by the discovery of thousands of exoplanets and the quest to identify Earth-like planets. Radial velocity (RV) observations have proven to be a powerful tool for detecting exoplanets, as they can reveal the architecture of planetary systems and measure planetary mass and orbital eccentricities. However, the detection of small exoplanets is hindered by complex, temporally correlated instrumental and astrophysical stochastic signals. In this review, we frame RV data analysis as a problem of detection and parameter estimation in unevenly sampled, multivariate time series. The objective of this review is to introduce the motivation, methodological challenges, and numerical challenges of RV data analysis to nonspecialists, and to unify the existing advanced approaches in order to identify areas for improvement.
